text: on Sunday 97 people in China died from
the corona virus that's the highest
number in a single day since this crisis
began
we know the death toll as a whole is now

well his President Xi in Beijing a

like many people have done the president

let's bring in Kerry Alan Chinese

thanks for joining is and tell us more

he visited Wuhan visited various

much since this coronavirus story

stay with us please a couple of other

while all of this has been playing out
Chinese workers are meant to be

he's robbing bread well here in Shanghai

most of the shops remain closed there's
a small number of people out there but

and the numbers of those coming back is

as well
well the BBC Steve McDonald has just

it's fine as long as we pay a little

let's bring in Carrie again from BBC

can't
she'd get to work because they need

I think there's a bit of leeway because

yeah there are jobs that are people are

well we've also heard from the World

there are cases of the virus in 24

we know he contracted the virus at a

a ski
Resort in France there the virus spread

that story has led to the phrase super

today that's when one patient infects
significant numbers of people you can
find much more detail on how that works
in this article on the BBC News website
it's really important to stress though
it's not the patient's fault as people
who are showing no symptoms at all can

example we found this study from The

when a corona virus known as MERS was a
big issue that included a super
spreading event that led to more than 80
people being infected by one person well
for more on how this virus appears to be

Roberts it appears that some people
might be able to pass the virus more
readily than others we don't know why so
experts so far had thought possibly
somebody who's infected might pass it to
two or three other people in this most
recent example it seems to be more than
that so hence the term super spreader
but it's not down to the individual is
just how the virus behaves in different

how this virus you know it's different

they've now been allowed to disembark

in Yokohama because there one cruise

another 65 cases have been confirmed
among passengers the ship's being

there are three thousand seven hundred

that was after a passenger disembarked

the highlight this laboratory in Wuhan

chose to write to general again wh o is

without vital diagnostic capacity
countries are in the dark as to how far

more on the difficulties of testing for
this virus on board a cruise ship here's
dr. Jennifer news o from Johns Hopkins
Bloomberg School of Public Health well I
think one of the challenges with these
cruise ships is you have everybody
captured at a moment in time and if it's
possible that they have been exposed and
are infected in by the virus then they
may show signs of that virus over the
next potentially up to two weeks and so
testing everyone at any moment in time
is going to be difficult to know truly
whether the person is infected or not
and I think this really speaks to one of
the challenges of trying to detain these
individuals and then decide whether or
not they're safe to go or not
particularly if they are on the ship and
then they're exposed to somebody who
then later develops an infection it sort
of begs the question whether they have
to start the clock over again for
another two weeks and whether that will
keep going in perpetuity depending on
how many people ultimately develop the
infection
